topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny opens by teasing Chip’s unusual path into Airbnb as a 52-year-old and the value of older perspectives. He introduces Chip’s career highlights (Joie de Vivre, Airbnb, MEA) and frames the conversation’s main arcs.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Great Question (UX research platform) and Vanta (security/compliance automation).

topics.title: Setting up the three career arcs
topics.summary: Lenny and Chip reconnect and outline the episode structure: Joie de Vivre, Airbnb, and Modern Elder Academy. They decide to start with the Airbnb chapter.

topics.title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
topics.summary: Chip recounts how a one-off talk turned into a consulting role and then full-time work, and what it felt like being older than almost everyone. He describes learning tech language, redefining “product,” and leading with humility while reporting to a younger CEO.

topics.title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
topics.summary: Chip shares candid lessons about Brian’s strengths (curiosity, learning mindset) and challenges (workaholism expectations, intense product reviews, unrealistic goals). He explains how he tried to influence Brian toward more emotionally intelligent leadership.

topics.title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
topics.summary: Chip offers practical meeting tactics: align on goals and success criteria upfront, keep decks minimal, and be ready for nonlinear discussions. He emphasizes earning credibility through deep customer exposure (e.g., host world tour).

topics.title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
topics.summary: Chip explains fluid vs. crystallized intelligence and why mixed-age teams outperform when they combine speed with systems thinking. He gives examples: advocating for older hosts in product decisions, anticipating regulation risk, and “invisible productivity” through elevating others.

topics.title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
topics.summary: Chip discusses how real ageism is (cost, perceived slowness, skill gaps) and how ERGs like “Wisdom at Airbnb” helped. He suggests flexible roles (60–80% time) and highlights the growing importance of human wisdom alongside AI.

topics.title: How to thrive in tech as you age
topics.summary: Chip identifies common traits of midlife professionals who keep thriving: curiosity, learner-teacher mindset, physical/positive energy, and approachability. He argues “age-fluid” presence matters more than chronology.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda, describing how Lenny uses it to run the podcast and community workflows.

topics.title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
topics.summary: Chip advises companies to prioritize generalists as AI accelerates execution, and to design mutual mentorship so older workers teach management/craft while younger workers teach tools/tech. He also suggests resume framing around thorny problems solved and measurable outcomes.

topics.title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
topics.summary: Chip tells the origin story of starting the Phoenix and growing Joie de Vivre into a major boutique hotel group, then burning out during the Great Recession. He foreshadows the near-death experience that catalyzed selling the company and opening space for Airbnb.

topics.title: Near-death experience and its life message
topics.summary: Chip describes flatlining repeatedly due to an antibiotic allergy and experiencing vivid imagery and “bird talk” urging him to slow down and notice beauty. The experience reshaped his priorities and accelerated major life changes.

topics.title: Culture as an operating system for companies
topics.summary: Chip explains culture as what happens when the boss isn’t around, especially critical in distributed/remote orgs. He contrasts culture fit vs. culture add and notes culture’s role in decision-making, hiring magnets, and employee experience.
